awd_titl_txt: RAISE-EQuIP: A Chip-integrated Platform for Photon-Efficient Quantum Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:

Quantum communication exploits the fundamental laws of physics to reliably secure private information networking even over untrusted channels. Despite rapid progresses in research and technology demonstrations, its large-scale deployment in practical settings still faces significant difficulties such as limited distance, low data rates, high susceptibility to channel disturbances, and disproportional operating overhead. This project aims to address those challenges by developing chip-integrated devices and sub-systems for preparation and detection of photonic signals in advantageous quantum states. They will be assembled to create innovative systems for line-of-sight applications robust against inferior weather conditions, ultra-efficient information encoding and decoding on single photons, and optimized hybrid quantum communication over both free space and optical fibers. This project will be carried out collaboratively by research groups from Stevens Institute of Technology and University of Texas at Arlington. Students from both institutes will be supported, motivated, and trained to work at the intersection of device integration, quantum optics, high-speed electro-optic circuits, and communication systems. A workforce with such balanced trainings and knowledge bases will contribute significantly to the industrial development of quantum technologies. At Stevens, a weekend-lab visit will be hosted each semester open to public to showcase the merging frontiers of quantum physics and nanophotonics. At Arlington, guided lab visits will be organized during the Engineering Week and K-12 summer camps. Both groups will continue to attract members from under-represented groups and help them launch scientific and engineering careers. 

Technical Abstract:  
This project will develop a highly-integrated quantum photonic platform based on lithium niobate thin films for modular quantum transceivers, whose unique capabilities include entanglement generation over 3.2-micron spectral spacing, lossless photon waveform shaping on a picosecond timescale, disruptive receiver technology based on mode-resolving photon detection, and ultrafast optical time-division de-multiplexing for fast quantum signals. With these offerings, this new device platform will host innovative techniques for fast, robust, and photon-efficient quantum communications over both telecom fibers and free space. Three quantum communication systems will be targeted in this project. The first is an innovative mid-IR channel for weatherproof quantum communication over free space, which not only multiplies the communication speed and reach but may also provide a reliable, high-speed ground-space link for quantum satellite applications through further development. The second is ultra-photon-efficient quantum key distribution using overlapping time-frequency modes to significantly increase the key rate while also strengthening the channel security. Meanwhile, quantum bit locking will also be explored by unitary scrambling and de-scrambling single photons, as an alternative approach to high-speed quantum encryption. The third is an optimized hybrid quantum key distribution system over free space and optical fibers that could form the basis for the future versatile, resilient quantum networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have studied and developed lithium niobate on insulator (LNOI) as a new material platform for quantum information processing. Specifically, during this project, we have made the following progress. (1) We have developed and perfected periodic poling techniques for LNOI, and demonstrated nearly ideal quasi phase matching for a variety of nonlinear optical processes. (2) We have tested the performance of the lithium niobate chips for quantum information processing, demonstrated ultraefficient photon pair generation and quantum frequency conversion on chip. (3) We have significantly improved the performance and efficiency of electro-optical modulation on chip, demonstrating low V-pi and high modulation extinction. (4) As an exploration of the lithium niobate nanophotonics for quantum computing applications, we have demonstrated photon conversion on chip, achieving a single photon conversion efficiency of 0.001%. While this is still far away from the single photon level interaction as having been long pursued, it marked a 100x improvement from the previous state of the art. 

To increase the photon efficiency for quantum communications, we have performed a series of quantum frequency conversion experiments in lithium niobate crystals, to study mode-selective photon counting that discriminates both the spatial and temporal modes. This could lead to new capabilities in free-space quantum communications.

Meanwhile, the University of Texas at Arlington has built upon its pioneering work on spatial-mode-selective quantum frequency converters for high-dimensional quantum communications over few-mode fibers (FMFs) to integrate such converters directly in the FMF. Proof-of-concept experiments on spatial-mode-selective frequency conversion have been performed in (LP00, LP11) and in optical-angular-momentum-compatible (LP11a, LP11b) mode bases. Furthermore, a scheme for generation of spatial-mode-entangled photon pairs has been developed, and the mode-selective nature of its underlying parametric processes has been experimentally demonstrated in these two mode bases. Practical issues in implementing quantum communications over FMF have been addressed by phase-synchronizing multiple pump sources via optical comb and by fabricating low-loss spatial-mode multiplexers / de-multiplexers.

On the educational side, the UTA has optimized a portable setup for a live demonstration of a WDM optical communication link with analog and high-speed digital signals over 11 km of fiber, which has been presented every semester to freshman engineering students, as well as to juniors in electromagnetics class. At Stevens, we have built a quantum teaching lab where students are trained to use the latest quantum nanophotonic chips we made in this project.

Overall, we have pushed multiple fronts for efficient quantum information processing and communications. Our main results include the development of lithium niobate nanophotonics and their applications for quantum information, demonstration of high-dimensional quantum states for quantum communications over few-mode fibers, and studies of hybrid spatial-temporal mode detection using quantum frequency conversion. They may find applications in areas of quantum communications, sensing, and computing.
